We refer to the Merck Manual and other medical sources for help. The CT finding of an irregular walled-off fluid collection suggests that the patient has developed an abscess. Antibiotics and CT-guided drainage should be initiated to treat the abscess. Appendectomy may be done later as an interval appendectomy. An immediate appendectomy or early surgical drainage is not appropriate in this case as it may increase the risk of complications such as wound infection and intra-abdominal abscess.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a fever, abdominal pain, and tenderness in the right lower quadrant, which suggest acute appendicitis. However, the presence of a walled-off fluid collection indicates that the appendix may have perforated or ruptured, making it difficult to determine the extent of the infection. Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management is antibiotics and CT-guided drainage to control the infection and reduce inflammation in the area. Once the infection has been controlled, a subsequent interval appendectomy can be performed to prevent future episodes of appendicitis. Options B and C are not appropriate because a prompt appendectomy is indicated only when the diagnosis of appendicitis is clear, which is not the case in this patient. Option D is not ideal because early surgical drainage can increase the risk of infection spread and is not necessary in the majority of cases.

We refer to medical literature to guide us. The imaging shows an obstruction caused by the fecalith which has resulted in an irregular walled-off fluid collection. Antibiotics and CT-guided drainage is the recommended next step in management as it can help relieve the infection and abscess, and may avoid the need for immediate surgery. Interval appendectomy can be considered later after the initial treatment with antibiotics and drainage.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and CT findings suggest acute appendicitis with an associated abscess. Antibiotics and CT-guided drainage are the most appropriate initial management. Interval appendectomy can be performed later to prevent recurrent attacks, but it is not the immediate priority. Early surgical drainage can be considered in unstable patients, but intravenous hydration seems to stabilize the patient, so it is not the most appropriate next step.
